author: Ella Boyd
title: Vail Resort Slammed By 40 Inches Of Snow Over The Holiday Weekend
text:
Vail Resort in Colorado gave the people what they wanted this weekend: face shots and fresh pow!
As it turns out, Utah wasn't the only state to benefit from the recent storm. In a post to Instagram yesterday, officials at Vail reported that "storm skiing has been full on the past few days, with nearly 40” in the last week!"
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Vail Mountain (@vailmtn)
Vail offered "a huge thank you to our operations teams and ski patrol for keeping us safe."
"With a break in the flakes tomorrow, we’re ready for some sun, despite cold temps. Make sure to bundle up, and be on the lookout for sunny skies and powder stashes."
There's nothing quite like a bluebird day after a period of stormy skiing. Bring on that clear visibility and dark goggles!
Vail isn't the only Colorado resort to get hammered with new snow.
According to the National Weather Service, as of January 16th, Arapahoe Peak saw 42 inches as of 4:53 p.m.
Breckenridge, got 6.5 inches as of 10:01 a.m. on the 14th.
Monday was the end of the week-long storm cycle at Steamboat that delivered about 43 inches at mid-mountain.
Telluride saw 14 inches over the last 72 hours.
Breckenridge came in hot with 36 inches over the last week , and 21 inches of that came in over the last two days.
Winter Park Resort got 26 inches over the last two days, and 35 inches over the last three days.
Crested Butte got 20 inches over the last 48 hours, and 48 inches in the last week.
Aspen Snowmass held its own with 8 inches in the last two days, and 10 inches in the last three days.
Last but certainly not least, Keystone got 16 inches in the last two days.
No matter where you're skiing this week, it's probably powder filled if it's anywhere in ColoRADo!

author: Philip Ward
title: Blood Drive in Honor of Rachel Clark at Humes in Waterford
text:
Blood Drive in Honor of Rachel Clark at Humes in Waterford
A blood drive in honor of Rachel Clark will be held at Humes Chrysler Jeep Dodge & Ram in Waterford on Thursday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.
Rachel diagnosed with Uterine Leiomyosarcoma (LMS), a rare and aggressive soft tissue cancer that required multiple blood transfusions needed to save her life... a disease that Clark continues to fight to this day.
Matt Clark, her father and General Manager of Humes Chrysler Jeep Dodge & Ram, has been with her every step of the way and talked about the journey Rachel has been on since the diagnosis.
"It has been pretty difficult but we are keeping the faith and we have a lot of reason for optimism," Clark said.
Clark also credited the Community Blood Bank with not only helping Rachel but always being there for the entire community.
"We found out firsthand how important it is and it truly is lifesaving.
"To see the dedicated folks that are there and the ongoing need for blood between cancer patients and people who need operations...there really is a never-ending need," Clark said.
He also said that Thursday will be an emotional day for the entire family seeing the community rally around them and help them out, just as the Clarks have done for so many others.
"Rachel is humbled and emotional and it gives her reason to stay positive because there are so many folks that are supporting her and love her and we are happy to be a part of the community here," he said.
If you would like to donate you can sign up here by scanning the QR code, walk-in to Humes, 1010 US-19, Waterford, PA 16441, between 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., or go to the Community Blood Bank, 2646 Peach St, Erie, PA 16508, between 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
